Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Catalytic Methods for the Enantioselective Synthesis of Enolizable Alpha-Amino and Alpha-Azido Aldehydes and Novel Applications Thereof
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Chemical Synthesis program supports the research and development of new methods for constructing alpha-amino aldehydes and related structures in the laboratory of Professor Thomas Coombs at the University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW). The nitrogen sources used in this work allow easy manipulation of the nitrogen protecting group following their union with aldehydes. The ability to remove this protecting group using mild reaction conditions is expected to permit a broader range of functionalized aldehydes to serve as starting materials in streamlined syntheses of nitrogen-containing small molecules. The alpha-amino aldehydes generated via these methods can be transformed into a range of nitrogen-containing compounds with potential applications in medicinal chemistry and chemical biology. The proposed chemistry uses organocatalysts and water in the key steps, contributing to the development of this line of catalytic bond construction. The University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW) has a strong tradition of training students in STEM fields. This award will allow Professor Coombs to extend hands-on research opportunities to both undergraduate and M.S.-level students interested in conducting original research in preparation for careers in chemical science. The projects funded in this proposal will be used to teach students how to approach research questions from a molecular perspective and to troubleshoot challenges encountered in the laboratory.

The proposed research is aimed at developing new methods for the enantioselective organocatalytic synthesis of enolizable alpha-amino aldehydes bearing sulfonamide protecting groups. These protecting groups may be removed under non-reductive conditions, permitting the incorporation of reducible functional groups in the starting aldehydes. Extending these methods to use tryptamines as reaction substrates for the synthesis of 3-amino-pyrroloindolines via a similar mechanism will also be investigated, as will the development of an enantioselective route to enolizable alpha-azido aldehydes for use in tandem reactions generating nitrogen heterocycles. The proposed research seeks to develop new enantioselective amination methods for streamlining organic synthesis.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Wilmington
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT WILMINGTON

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Wilmington

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developing improved catalytic methods for the enantioselective construction of carbon-nitrogen bonds is essential for the advancement of modern synthetic approaches to nitrogen-containing compounds of importance to society.  During the period of this NSF grant support, our initial discovery that a commonly used, commercial organocatalyst (MacMillan's second-generation imidazolidinone) promoted the synthesis of alpha-amino aldehydes from simple starting materials was thoroughly investigated.  As alpha-amino aldehydes are direct precursors to both amino acids and amino alcohols, this method has the potential to facilitate basic research in fields such as medicinal chemistry, biochemistry, polymer science, and related disciplines.  Furthermore, the numerous nitrogen-containing compound types easily derived from alpha-amino aldehydes should find ready application as starting materials or monomers for research scientists seeking to advance new compounds or materials with novel biological functions or other useful properties. 

Our method uses ortho-nitrobenzenesulfonyl azide (o-NsN3) as the electrophilic nitrogen source for carbon-nitrogen bond formation, distinguishing it from many common organocatalytic amination protocols.  This feature permits unmasking of the newly-installed amine without resort to reductive conditions, broadening the range of functional groups tolerated in the overall synthesis sequence (from unsubstituted aldehyde to alpha-amino acid, for instance) and offering the potential benefit of shorter approaches to desired non-natural amino acids having a variety of structures.  Further distinguishing our method from related organocatalytic alpha-amination protocols employing sulfonyl azides is its use of alpha-unsubstituted aldehydes.  Such aldehydes lead to amino acids of the type most commonly found in peptides and proteins, bearing a hydrogen atom on the carbon between the amine and the carboxylic acid functional groups.  This protocol, therefore, enables the synthesis of non-natural amino acids and peptides where structural modifications are located on the sidechains rather than the peptide backbone. 

Several particularly notable discoveries were made during our investigations.   First, MacMillan's second-generation imidazolidinone was uniquely capable of promoting the desired carbon-nitrogen bond formation, with other commercially available MacMillan imidazolidinones, proline, and prolinol derivatives failing in the reaction or delivering very low product yields.  Second, performing the reaction in common organic solvents produced low yields of amination product, while running the reaction in the absence of solvent (neat) or as a biphasic mixture in the presence of water led to significant yield enhancements.  Adding very small quantities of ethyl acetate as a co-solvent enabled successful alpha-amination of solid and semisolid aldehydes.  Third, the reaction worked best using hydrocinnamaldehyde derivatives (3-arylpropanals), a specific structural class of aldehydes substituted with aromatic rings.  A striking reactivity pattern was observed wherein hydrocinnamaldehydes bearing electron-rich aromatic rings afforded much higher amination product yields than those bearing electron-deficient aromatics.  Fourth, enantiomeric excesses of 90% or greater were observed across all substrates evaluated.  This outcome is especially important if the reaction is to be used in medicinal chemistry applications where single enantiomers of biologically active compounds are especially desirable.

To demonstrate one of the project's key goals--the synthesis of important medicinal and biochemical building blocks, such as amino acids, containing functional groups susceptible to reduction--a nitro-substituted analog of phenylalanine was targeted.  Following oxidation to the carboxylic acid and removal of the o-Ns nitrogen protecting group to liberate the free amine under mild conditions, the desired amino acid was isolated via ion exchange chromatography. 

The results of our study suggest that stabilization of a cationic intermediate during the catalytic cycle may be key to improving reaction efficiency.  We currently hypothesize that the aromatic rings of the aldehyde substrate and imidazolidinone catalyst play a role in stabilizing this cation.  New catalyst evaluation and collaborative computational efforts are ongoing to investigate this hypothesis and broaden the aldehyde substrate scope of the reaction. 

A second area of investigation during the period of this grant centered on the advancement of a general synthetic approach to enantiomerically-enriched alpha-azido aldehydes.  These compounds are expected to enable the development of new tandem reaction sequences for the synthesis of heterocycles commonly found in medicinal agents.  Reaction conditions for the enantiospecific synthesis of the desired alpha-azido aldehydes have been worked out and optimization of these protocols is continuing in preparation for future application investigation.

Modified by: Thomas C Coombs

    Thomas Coombs
    Public Domain
    Thomas C Coombs
    Alpha-Amination of Aldehydes
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Developing improved catalytic methods for the enantioselective construction of carbon-nitrogen bonds is essential for the advancement of modern synthetic approaches to nitrogen-containing compounds of importance to society. During the period of this NSF grant support, our initial discovery that a commonly used, commercial organocatalyst (MacMillan's second-generation imidazolidinone) promoted the synthesis of alpha-amino aldehydes from simple starting materials was thoroughly investigated. As alpha-amino aldehydes are direct precursors to both amino acids and amino alcohols, this method has the potential to facilitate basic research in fields such as medicinal chemistry, biochemistry, polymer science, and related disciplines. Furthermore, the numerous nitrogen-containing compound types easily derived from alpha-amino aldehydes should find ready application as starting materials or monomers for research scientists seeking to advance new compounds or materials with novel biological functions or other useful properties. Our method uses ortho-nitrobenzenesulfonyl azide (o-NsN3) as the electrophilic nitrogen source for carbon-nitrogen bond formation, distinguishing it from many common organocatalytic amination protocols. This feature permits unmasking of the newly-installed amine without resort to reductive conditions, broadening the range of functional groups tolerated in the overall synthesis sequence (from unsubstituted aldehyde to alpha-amino acid, for instance) and offering the potential benefit of shorter approaches to desired non-natural amino acids having a variety of structures. Further distinguishing our method from related organocatalytic alpha-amination protocols employing sulfonyl azides is its use of alpha-unsubstituted aldehydes. Such aldehydes lead to amino acids of the type most commonly found in peptides and proteins, bearing a hydrogen atom on the carbon between the amine and the carboxylic acid functional groups. This protocol, therefore, enables the synthesis of non-natural amino acids and peptides where structural modifications are located on the sidechains rather than the peptide backbone. Several particularly notable discoveries were made during our investigations. First, MacMillan's second-generation imidazolidinone was uniquely capable of promoting the desired carbon-nitrogen bond formation, with other commercially available MacMillan imidazolidinones, proline, and prolinol derivatives failing in the reaction or delivering very low product yields. Second, performing the reaction in common organic solvents produced low yields of amination product, while running the reaction in the absence of solvent (neat) or as a biphasic mixture in the presence of water led to significant yield enhancements. Adding very small quantities of ethyl acetate as a co-solvent enabled successful alpha-amination of solid and semisolid aldehydes. Third, the reaction worked best using hydrocinnamaldehyde derivatives (3-arylpropanals), a specific structural class of aldehydes substituted with aromatic rings. A striking reactivity pattern was observed wherein hydrocinnamaldehydes bearing electron-rich aromatic rings afforded much higher amination product yields than those bearing electron-deficient aromatics. Fourth, enantiomeric excesses of 90% or greater were observed across all substrates evaluated. This outcome is especially important if the reaction is to be used in medicinal chemistry applications where single enantiomers of biologically active compounds are especially desirable. To demonstrate one of the project's key goals--the synthesis of important medicinal and biochemical building blocks, such as amino acids, containing functional groups susceptible to reduction--a nitro-substituted analog of phenylalanine was targeted. Following oxidation to the carboxylic acid and removal of the o-Ns nitrogen protecting group to liberate the free amine under mild conditions, the desired amino acid was isolated via ion exchange chromatography. The results of our study suggest that stabilization of a cationic intermediate during the catalytic cycle may be key to improving reaction efficiency. We currently hypothesize that the aromatic rings of the aldehyde substrate and imidazolidinone catalyst play a role in stabilizing this cation. New catalyst evaluation and collaborative computational efforts are ongoing to investigate this hypothesis and broaden the aldehyde substrate scope of the reaction. A second area of investigation during the period of this grant centered on the advancement of a general synthetic approach to enantiomerically-enriched alpha-azido aldehydes. These compounds are expected to enable the development of new tandem reaction sequences for the synthesis of heterocycles commonly found in medicinal agents. Reaction conditions for the enantiospecific synthesis of the desired alpha-azido aldehydes have been worked out and optimization of these protocols is continuing in preparation for future application investigation.
